snippet.title: A giant [bleep] for Kevin Dopart
snippet.description: The Invite's top scorer for 7 years gets Ink 1K with a classic anagram. Here are some more of his winners.

snippet.title: $20 Diner: Kenyan mash-ups make for thrilling cheap eats at Swahili Village
snippet.description: Beltsville restaurant showcases the global influences on East African cooking.

snippet.title: The sequester dining guide
snippet.description: During these dark sequestered days, we need cheap eats more than ever.

snippet.title: The $20 Diner Manifesto
snippet.description: Our inability to cover a tab at Minibar is no reason to shed a tear into our deconstructed beer. We simply need to widen our dining worldview.

snippet.title: Style Invitational Week 977 results: Twisting the tongues of Google Translate
snippet.description: Results of the Style Invitational's contest to trip up Google's hard-to-fool translation tool.

snippet.title: Can schools teach teens how to handle money?
snippet.description: Coming of age in the great recession has made students more aware of financial concerns, but it hasn't provided them the tools to be more financially responsible. Local educators have recognized this and last September, Virginia became the fourth state to implement a mandatory class in personal finance .for all in-coming freshmen. And Maryland just became one of twenty states to adopt an "integrated" approach to teaching these subjects, folding them into social studies and math. But will these new courses make teens more responsible than their parents?

snippet.title: Field of Dreams
snippet.description: "Outcasts United" by Warren St. John shows how a soccer team of refugees can transform an American town.

snippet.title: Lost in America, Found on a Field
snippet.description: How a soccer team of refugees transformed an American town.

snippet.title: The Pleasure Is in the Pain
snippet.description: Even people who are otherwise gastronomically conservative will eat chili-pepper-spiked food as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

snippet.title: Springfield Church Welcomes Many Nations Under God
snippet.description: Even in an era of mass immigration that has produced suburban tamale shops alongside halal meat markets and created a market for television programming in Hindi and Arabic, places of worship remain bastions of racial and ethnic uniformity. And that makes the case of one brick church in Springfiel...
